title: S&P 500 index on track for all-time closing high as stocks edge higher
text:
U.S. stocks extended modest gains Friday, with the benchmark S&P 500 index trading above its all-time closing high of 3,025.86 set on July 26, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average was boosted by a jump in Intel stock after earnings beat estimates, as the busiest week of the third quarter corporate earnings reporting season winds down.

Geopolitical risks were also a concern with the European Union debating another delay to Brexit, but stocks also received a boost from reports the U.S. and China were close to finalizing some sections of a recently agreed trade deal.

How are major indexes faring?

The S&P 500 index SPX, +0.40% traded as high as 3,027.35, shy of its intraday record of 3,027.98, also set on July 26. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.64% meanwhile, was around 188 pints higher at 26,993, a gain of 0.7% and below its all-time closing high of 27,359.16, also set in July. The Nasdaq Composite COMP, +0.59% was up 52 points or 0.6% at 8,238.

On Thursday, the Dow DJIA, +0.64% closed 28.42 points, or 0.11%, lower, at 26,805.53, with a decline in shares of Post-it maker 3M weighing on the index. The S&P 500 index SPX, +0.40%, meanwhile, gained 5.77 points to 3,010.29, while the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, +0.59% added 66 points, or 0.81%, at 8,185.80.

For the week, the S&P 500 is on track to post a 0.8% weekly gain, the Nasdaq is poised for a 1.8% weekly rise while the Dow is set for a more modest 0.1% gain, as of Thursday’s close.

What’s driving the market?

Corporate earnings results remain the catalyst for the stock market this week, with earnings from Intel and Amazon.com the focus.

Intel INTC, +7.39% shares rose after better-than-expected earnings and revenue but Amazon AMZN, -1.40% disappointed investors with its third-quarter results sending the stock down,

More than 38% of S&P 500 companies posted quarter earnings for the third quarter thus far, according to FactSet. Of those companies, 78% have beaten analyst expectations.

See: Intel stock shoots higher but one key number has analysts worried

“We expect the trend in earnings results to be similar to previous quarters, where consensus reduced estimates into the reporting season, only to be revised higher as the results were out,” J.P. Morgan Cazenove analyst Mislav Matejka wrote. “EPS estimates for the third quarter have now fallen below Q2 2019 delivered EPS. This is way too conservative, in our view.”

See: Amazon earnings miss is the price of growth, analysts say

Investors also are closely following developments related to Britain’s exit from the European Union and the status of U.S. - China trade talks as global economic growth slows.

French President Emmanuel Macron blocked the EU’s attempt to delay Brexit for three months, but the European Commission said work on this would “continue in the coming days”.

The U.S. and China have made progress in trade talks and come close to finalizing parts of a phase one deal, CNBC reported Friday, citing the U.S. Trade Representative’s office. However, doubts remain that a substantive U.S. - China trade agreement can be finalized. Top U.S. and Chinese trade officials are discussing plans on Friday for China to buy more U.S. farm products, but in return, Beijing will request cancellation of some planned and existing U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports, people briefed on the talks told Reuters.

In U.S. economic news, the University of Michigan’s consumer sentiment index fell to 95.5 in October, from 96.0. “The economy is still in a good place consumers feel for now,” MUFG chief economist Chris Rupkey said. “The consumer is more than willing to go it alone if necessary when it comes to the heavy lifting of the economy that is required for growth as business investment spending weakens due to the uncertainty caused by trade war tensions.”

Which stocks are in focus?

Intel Corp. INTC, +7.39% shares rose 7% after the chip maker raised its outlook for the year on Thursday evening after it posted an increase in third-quarter earnings.

Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -1.40% dropped 3% on Friday after the tech giant reported a 26% fall in profit late Thursday as it invested heavily to speed up shipping times.

Verizon Communications Inc. VZ, -0.39% stock gained after an earnings beat. The telecommunications giant added new phone subscribers and net income attributable to Verizon was $5.19 billion, up from $4.92 billion a year earlier. Quarterly revenue edged up slightly to $32.9 billion from $32.6 billion a year ago.

Boeing Co.’s BA, -1.13% 737 MAX was blamed formally in the Lion Air fatal nose dive into the Java Sea nearly a year ago by Indonesia investigators.

How are other markets performing?

Treasury yields were little changed on Friday as a lack of fresh developments on Brexit and U.S-China trade drew investors’ attention to next week’s Federal Reserve meeting, where another quarter point rate cut is expected. The 10-year Treasury note yield TMUBMUSD10Y, +2.15% was up 0.4 basis point to 1.770%,

Oil futures drifted into negative territory Friday, but remained on track for weekly gains as concerns over supply appeared to take over the spotlight from longer-term worries over global economic growth and the outlook for crude demand. West Texas Intermediate crude for December CLZ19, +0.12% on the New York Mercantile Exchange was off 10 cents, or 0.2%, at $56.13 a barrel, but was on track for a 4.4% weekly advance after ending Thursday at a nearly one-month high.

Gold futures extended a gain above a key $1,500 price on Friday and looked poised to carve out a fresh near-term settlement high as investors positioned for more easing from global central banks, which could add further support for bullion. December gold GCZ19, +0.21% on Comex gained $9.20, or 0.6%, to $1,514.20 an ounce, which would mark the highest close for the most-active contract since Oct. 4, if it holds, according to FactSet data, following a 0.6% gain for the metal on Thursday.

European stocks edged lower on Friday. After closing Thursday at its highest level since Jan. 29, 2018, the Stoxx Europe 600 SXXP, +0.16% declined 0.12% to 396.91.

In Asia, Japan’s Nikkei NIK, +0.22% gave up early gains after Trade Minister Isshu Sugawara resigned after just a month on the job.

Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index HSI, -0.49% fell 0.4%, while the Shanghai Composite SHCOMP, +0.48% slipped 0.2% and the smaller-cap Shenzhen Composite 399106, +0.99% rose slightly.
